sect1.title: Serologic Classification
sect1.para: The genusLeptospira comprises spiral-shaped bacteria with hooked ends (1). This genus, along with the genera Leptonema and Turneriella, makes up the family Leptospiraceae in the order Spirochaetales and class Spirochaetes of the phylum Spirochaetae (2). The genus was formerly divided into two species: Leptospira interrogans, comprising all pathogenic strains, and L. biflexa, containing the saprophytic strains isolated from the environment (3). L. biflexa and L. interrogans were differentiated by a number of biochemical tests (3).

Leptospires are divided into serovars defined by agglutination after cross-absorption with homologous antigen (4, 5). Serovars are considered distinct if more than 10% of the homologous titer remains in at least one of the two antisera on repeated testing (6). Over 60 serovars of L. biflexa sensu lato and more than 200 serovars of L. interrogans sensu lato are recognized. Serovars that are antigenically related have traditionally been grouped into serogroups (5). Serogroups have no taxonomic standing, but the concept has proved useful for epidemiological understanding, in part due to its differential power (260+ serogroups compared to only 67 species), particularly when interpreting the serological results from the microscopic agglutination test (MAT).

sect1.title: Genotypic Classification
sect1.para: The phenotypic classification of leptospires has been replaced by a genotypic one, in which 67 genomospecies include all serovars ofLeptospira (7). Leptospira has a genome size of 3.9 to 4.6 megabases, most of which is composed of the larger of its two chromosomes (8). A list of validated Leptospira spp. can be found at https://www.bacterio.net/genus/leptospira. DNA hybridization studies have also confirmed the taxonomic status of the genera Leptonema (9) and Turneriella (10); each genus currently includes a single species. The genetically defined species of Leptospira do not correspond to the previous two phenotypic species (L. interrogans sensu lato and L. biflexa sensu lato) (11). Neither serogroup nor serovar reliably predicts the species of Leptospira. Moreover, genetic heterogeneity resulting from horizontal transfer of genes coding for cell surface antigens occurs within serovars (9, 12, 13), resulting in strains of some serovars being classified in multiple species, most notably the two genotypes of serovar Hardjo (L. interrogans serovar Hardjo subtype Hardjoprajitno and L. borgpetersenii serovar Hardjo subtype Hardjobovis) (14, 15). In addition, the phenotypic characteristics formerly used to differentiate L. interrogans sensu lato from L. biflexa sensu lato do not differentiate the genetically defined species (9, 16). Both L. interrogans and L. biflexa are retained as specific names in the genomic classification, and in this chapter, specific names refer to the genetically defined species, including L. interrogans sensu stricto and L. biflexa sensu stricto.

Classification of leptospires requires the identification of both species and serovar of each isolate. Identification ofLeptospira species is readily accomplished by sequencing of conserved housekeeping genes (17, 18), by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) (19), or by using average nucleotide identity (ANI) analysis (20). Phylogenetic analysis of rrs (16S rRNA) and ppk (polyphosphate kinase) gene sequences demonstrates the two clades of leptospires, designated pathogens (P) and saprophytes (S), each containing two subclades (P1 and P2, S1 and S2) (Fig. 1). Genomes of several hundred strains of Leptospira have been sequenced, starting with representative reference strains (18), providing valuable information that can be used for taxonomy, including species identification (Fig. 2). Already there are nearly 1,000 whole-genome assemblies for the genus Leptospira in the NCBI database, reflecting increased use of whole-genome sequencing. As molecular technologies and bioinformatics allow more powerful and complete analyses, classification schemes for Leptospira spp. may move away from traditional serovar classification and instead rely on typing schemes based on genomic sequencing (21).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE FAMILY
sect2.para: Leptospires are tightly coiled spirochetes, usually 0.1 μm wide by 6 to 20 μm long. The helical conformation is right-handed, while the amplitude is approximately 0.1 to 0.15 μm and the wavelength is approximately 0.5 μm (22). The cells have pointed ends, either or both of which are usually bent into a distinctive hook (Fig. 3). Two axial filaments (periplasmic flagella) with polar insertions are located in the periplasmic space. Leptospires exhibit two distinct forms of movement, either translational (rapid back-and-forth movements) or rotational (spinning rapidly about the long axis of the cell) (22). Morphologically, all leptospires are indistinguishable.

For rrs, sequences were extracted from the species type strain genome assemblies from NCBI’s RefSeq database, except for nine species that did not have a representative 16S sequence, which were extracted from genome assemblies in NCBI’s GenBank database. sect2.para: Leptospires are obligate aerobes with an optimum growth temperature of 28 to 30°C. The optimum pH for growth is 7.2 to 7.6. They produce both catalase and oxidase. They grow in simple media enriched with vitamins (vitamins B2 and B12 are growth factors), long-chain fatty acids, and ammonium salts (3).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Leptospires are ubiquitous, either free-living in water or wet soil, or associated with renal colonization of mammals. Leptospirosis is presumed to be the most widespread zoonosis in the world (23) and is estimated to cause more than a million cases per year globally (24). The source of infection in humans is usually either direct or indirect contact with the urine of an infected animal. The incidence is much higher in warm-climate countries than in temperate regions, due mainly to longer survival of leptospires in the environment under warm, humid conditions. Leptospirosis is seasonal. Peak incidence occurs in summer or fall in temperate regions, where temperature is the limiting factor in survival of leptospires, and during rainy seasons in warm climate regions, where rapid desiccation would otherwise prevent survival.

Animals, including humans, can be categorized as maintenance hosts or accidental (incidental) hosts. A maintenance host is defined as a species in which infection is endemic, usually transferred from animal to animal by direct contact. Infection is usually acquired at an early age, and the prevalence of chronic excretion in the urine increases with the age of the animal. Other mammals (such as humans) may become incidental hosts when they are infected by direct or indirect contact with the maintenance host. Animals may be maintenance hosts of some serovars but incidental hosts of others, infection with which may cause severe or fatal disease. The most important maintenance hosts are small mammals, which may transfer infection to domestic farm animals, dogs, and humans. Different rodent species may be reservoirs of distinct serovars, but rats are generally maintenance hosts for serovars of the serogroup Icterohaemorrhagiae, as are mice for serogroup Ballum serovars. Domestic animals are also maintenance hosts; dairy cattle may harbor serovars Hardjo and Pomona, pigs Pomona, Tarassovi, or Bratislava, and dogs Canicola. Distinct variations in maintenance hosts and the serovars they carry occur throughout the world, and these associations may change over time.

Knowledge of the prevalent serovars and their maintenance hosts is essential for understanding the epidemiology of the disease. For example, the incidence of canine leptospirosis has increased in the northeastern regions of North America over the last 20 years. Serology and molecular characterization suggest that it is caused largely by serovar Grippotyphosa (25–27). Epidemiological evidence implicates raccoons (28) and possibly skunks as the reservoir. Cases are clustered particularly in newly suburbanized areas (26). This change in epidemiology has led to the inclusion of serovars Grippotyphosa and Pomona in canine vaccines (29).

Human infections may be acquired through occupational, recreational, or avocational exposures. Occupation remains a significant risk factor for humans. Direct contact with infected animals accounts for most infections in farmers, veterinarians, abattoir workers, rodent control workers, and others whose occupations require contact with animals, while indirect contact is important for sewer workers, miners, soldiers, septic tank cleaners, fish farmers, rice field workers, and sugar cane cutters. Livestock farming is a major occupational risk factor throughout the world. There is a significant risk associated with recreational exposures occurring in water sports (30). The increasing popularity of adventure sports and ecotourism has led to an increase in leptospirosis in travelers (31, 32).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: The usual portal of entry is through abrasions or cuts in the skin, or via the mucous membranes. The great majority of infections are either subclinical or of very mild severity, and patients will probably not seek medical attention. The clinical presentation of leptospirosis is biphasic, with a septicemic phase lasting about a week, followed by the immune phase, characterized by antibody production and excretion of leptospires in the urine. Most of the complications of leptospirosis are associated with localization of leptospires within the tissues during the immune phase and thus occur during the second week of the illness.

The overwhelming majority of recognized cases present with a febrile illness of sudden onset, the symptoms of which include chills, headache, myalgia, abdominal pain, and conjunctival suffusion. Aseptic meningitis may be found in up to 25% of all leptospirosis cases. Between 5 and 10% of all patients with leptospirosis have the icteric form of the disease (Weil’s disease), in which patients may develop jaundice, acute renal failure, and sometimes pulmonary hemorrhage or cardiac arrhythmias. Severe cases often present late in the course of the disease, and this contributes to the high mortality rate, which ranges between 5 and 15%. Although rare, some patients present with hemoptysis and pulmonary symptoms (33), which may progress very rapidly to severe pulmonary hemorrhagic syndrome (34).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Leptospires can be isolated from blood, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and peritoneal dialysate fluids during the first 10 days of illness. If possible, specimens should be collected before antibiotic therapy is initiated and while the patient is febrile; however, this should not delay initiation of antibiotic therapy. Under optimal conditions, one or two drops of venous blood are inoculated directly into culture medium at the bedside or as soon as possible after collection. While no transport medium exists forLeptospira, survival of leptospires in commercial blood culture medium for several days has been reported (35). Blood collected in citrate or EDTA is optimal for PCR detection, whereas use of collection tubes containing heparin, sodium polyanethol sulfonate, or saponin can inhibit PCR (36, 37).

Urine can be cultured after the first week of illness, during the second week following onset. Specimens should be collected aseptically in sterile containers without preservatives and must be processed within a short time of collection; best results are obtained when the delay is less than 1 h at ambient temperature. If culture is not possible, urine specimens intended for PCR testing may be frozen or stabilized at ambient temperature using one of several commercial products for this purpose, allowing transport over long distances (37).

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: Leptospires may be visualized in clinical material by dark-field microscopy (×100 and ×400 magnification) or by immunofluorescence or light microscopy after appropriate staining. Dark-field microscopic examination of body fluids, such as blood, urine, CSF, or dialysate fluid, is insensitive and lacks specificity (38). Approximately 104 leptospires/mL are necessary for one cell per field to be visible by dark-field microscopy (39). Direct dark-field microscopy of blood is also subject to misinterpretation of fibrin or protein threads, which may demonstrate Brownian motion (39, 40). Leptospires in tissues were first visualized by silver staining (41), and the Warthin-Starry stain is widely used for histologic examination. More recently, immunohistochemical methods have been applied (42, 43). Immunohistochemical staining can be performed at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, GA (contact the Infectious Disease Pathology Branch prior to shipping specimens [e-mail pathology@cdc.gov]).

sect1.title: Antigen Detection
sect1.para: Antigen detection is generally regarded as insensitive and is not commercially available.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), such as PCR, have been widely used for detection of leptospires. Leptospiral DNA has been amplified from blood, plasma, serum, urine, aqueous humor, CSF, and tissues obtained at autopsy (44) or biopsy.

Clinical evaluations have shown that PCR detection of leptospiral DNA is comparable to, or more sensitive than, diagnosis by culture (45–48), while serologic diagnosis of cases by testing acute- and convalescent-phase sera using the MAT remains more sensitive (46, 48). The principal advantage of NAATs is the ability to confirm the diagnosis during the acute illness, when treatment is likely to be most effective (49).

Real-time PCR assays have been applied to quantify the burden of infecting organisms in human cases and animal models (48, 50–52), as well as identification of common species (53). A limitation of PCR-based diagnosis of leptospirosis is the inability of most PCR assays to identify the infecting strain (15, 53), although molecular characterization is sometimes possible directly from clinical specimens (54, 55). While strain identification is not significant for individual patient management, the identity of the isolate has both epidemiological and public health value.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Leptospiremia occurs during the first stage of the disease, beginning before the onset of symptoms, and is usually finished by the end of the first week of the acute illness (56). Therefore, blood cultures should be done as soon as possible after the patient’s presentation. One or two drops of blood (approximately 50 μL) are inoculated into 10 mL of semisolid oleic acid-albumin medium (57, 58), such as Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH; BD Difco) containing 0.1% agar and 200 μg/mL 5-fluorouracil, at the patient’s bedside. Blood is allowed to drop onto the surface of the medium without mixing. Care should be taken to avoid overinoculation of the medium, as blood contains inhibitors of leptospiral growth. For the greatest recovery rate, multiple cultures should be performed, but this is rarely possible. Survival of leptospires in commercial blood culture media for up to a week has been reported (35, 59). Thus, if leptospirosis was not initially suspected, blood cultures may be used as a source for PCR testing if other samples are no longer available.

Other samples that can be cultured during the first week of illness include CSF and peritoneal dialysate. Urine cultures can yield growth from the beginning of the second week of symptomatic illness. Survival of leptospires in voided human urine is limited, so urine should be processed immediately by neutralization of pH with sodium bicarbonate followed by centrifugation. After centrifugation in conical tubes for 30 min at 1,500 ×g, the sediment is resuspended in 1 mL of phosphate-buffered saline, and 1 or 2 drops are inoculated into semisolid EMJH medium containing 5-fluorouracil as described above.

Cultures in EMJH are incubated at 28 to 30°C and examined weekly by dark-field microscopy for at least 13 weeks before being discarded. Growth often develops in a discrete band several millimeters below the surface of the medium, known as a Dinger’s ring. Cultures that show growth of other bacteria may be passed through a 0.2-μm or 0.45-μm filter before subculture into fresh medium.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Isolated leptospires are identified either by serological methods or by sequence-based techniques. Traditional methods relied on cross-agglutinin absorption (4), but the number of laboratories that can perform these identification methods is very small. The use of panels of monoclonal antibodies allows laboratories which can perform the MAT to identify isolates of frequently encountered serovars with relative rapidity (60). Monoclonal antibodies are available from the WHO/OIE Leptospirosis Reference Centre at the Academic Medical Centre (AMC), Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

The current serological taxonomy ofLeptospira necessitates the identification of isolates to both species and serovar levels. Species identification is most practically determined by sequence analysis (61) using the ppk gene (2). Other useful targets are the rrs (62), gyrB (B subunit of DNA gyrase) (63), rpoB (β subunit of RNA polymerase) (64), flaB (flagellin), and secY (secretory pathway) (65) genes. ANI from whole-genome sequences can be used for identification to species level (2) (Fig. 2). Species-level identification of leptospires using MALDI-TOF MS has also been reported (19, 66). Four species (L. interrogans, L. kirschneri, L. borgpetersenii, and L. santarosai) are included in MicrobeNet’s MALDI-TOF database (https://www.cdc.gov/microbenet/index.html). No modifications are required for species-level identification of Leptospira using MALDI-TOF, although further characterization to the serotype level is generally not possible.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Because of the difficulties associated with serological identification of leptospiral isolates, there has been great interest in molecular methods for identification and subtyping (61, 67). Methods employed have included digestion of chromosomal DNA by restriction endonucleases, restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (68, 69) ribotyping, and a number of PCR-based approaches (61).

Because of the decreasing costs of sequencing and the availability of bioinformatics tools, these have the potential to replace other typing methods. The public databasehttp://pubmlst.org/leptospira/ (70) hosts three multilocus sequence typing (MLST) schemes for Leptospira and contains more than 1,500 isolates that can be queried using sequences from whole genomes or individual genes (71–74). The database https://pubmlst.org/software/bigsdb/ allows high-resolution typing based on core genome MLST (cgMLST) as whole-genome sequencing becomes more commonplace (21). Advancements in molecular technologies have been successful in characterization directly from clinical specimens; however, the small amount of nucleic acids extracted from clinical specimens often prevents complete characterization of the infecting strain, since the bacterial load required for successful molecular profiling is high (53, 54, 75–77). The application of these approaches will lead to greater understanding of leptospiral epidemiology at the population level (27, 61, 78–81).

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Leptospirosis is commonly diagnosed by serology. Antibodies are detectable in the blood approximately 5 to 7 days after the onset of symptoms. The definitive serologic investigation of leptospirosis remains the MAT, in which patients’ sera are reacted with live antigen suspensions of leptospiral serovars. After incubation, the serum-antigen mixtures are examined microscopically for agglutination, and the titers are determined. The MAT is a complex test to control, perform, and interpret (82), and its use is limited to regional or national reference laboratories. Protocols for performing the MAT have been described in detail (40, 83). An international proficiency testing scheme under the auspices of the International Leptospirosis Society has stimulated improvement in the performance of the MAT by participating laboratories (84). The range of antigens used should include serovars representative of all serogroups (40, 82). The wide range of antigens is used to detect infections with uncommon, or previously undetected, serovars. The test is read by dark-field microscopy. The end point is the highest dilution of serum in which 50% agglutination occurs and is determined by the presence of approximately 50% free, unagglutinated leptospires by comparison with the control suspension (40). Considerable effort is required to reduce the subjective effect of observer variation, even within laboratories.

Interpretation of the MAT is complicated by the high degree of cross-reaction that occurs between different serogroups, especially in acute-phase samples. Paradoxical reactions, in which the highest titers detected are antibodies to a serogroup unrelated to the infecting one, are also common (11). The broad cross-reactivity in the acute phase, followed by relative serogroup specificity in convalescent-phase samples, results from the detection in the MAT of both IgM and IgG antibodies and the presence of several common antigens among leptospires (85).

Paired sera are required to confirm a serologic diagnosis with certainty. A 4-fold or greater rise in titer between paired sera confirms the diagnosis, regardless of the interval between samples. The interval between first and second samples depends very much on the delay between onset of symptoms and presentation of the patient. If symptoms typical of leptospirosis are present, an interval of 3 to 5 days may be adequate to detect rising titers. However, if the patient presents earlier in the course of the disease, or if the date of onset is not known precisely, then an interval of 10 to 14 days between samples is more appropriate. Less often, seroconversion does not occur with such rapidity, and a longer interval between samples (or repeated sampling) is necessary. MAT serology is insensitive, particularly in early acute-phase specimens (86, 87). Moreover, patients with fulminant leptospirosis may die before seroconversion occurs (87, 88).

A presumptive diagnosis can be made by detection of a single elevated titer in association with an acute febrile illness. The magnitude of such a titer is dependent upon the background level of exposure in the population, and hence the seroprevalence.

Titers following acute infection may be extremely high (≥25,600) and may take months, or even years, to fall to low levels (89, 90). Thus, in a high-incidence population, a low cutoff titer for presumptive diagnosis is inappropriate and will generate many false-positive diagnoses (91). In areas where the disease is endemic, a single titer of ≥800 in symptomatic patients is generally indicative of leptospirosis, but cutoff titers as high as ≥1,600 have been recommended (83). Rarely, seroconversion may be delayed for many weeks after recovery, and longer serological follow-up will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Formalin-treated antigens have been used in the MAT to overcome some of the difficulties associated with the use of live antigens. Titers obtained with these antigens are somewhat lower, and more cross-reactions are detected (40). These antigens are not available commercially but may be obtained from WHO Collaborating Centers.

The MAT is the most appropriate test to employ in epidemiological serosurveys, because it can be applied to sera from any animal species and because the range of antigens utilized can be expanded or decreased as required. It is usual to use a titer of ≥100 as evidence of past exposure (82). Contrary to a widely held belief, the MAT is a serogroup-specific assay. However, conclusions about infecting serovars cannot be drawn without isolates; at best, the MAT data can give a general impression of which serogroups are present within a population (92–94).

Because of the complexity of the MAT, rapid screening tests for leptospiral antibodies in acute infection have been developed. Traditional methods based upon agglutination have largely been superseded by IgM detection assays. IgM antibodies become detectable during the first week of illness, allowing the diagnosis to be confirmed and treatment to be initiated while it is likely to be most effective. IgM detection has repeatedly been shown to be more sensitive than MAT when the first specimen is taken early in the acute phase of the illness (87, 95, 96), although ideally rapid tests have the highest sensitivity after 10 days of symptoms (97). IgM dipstick assays have been shown to be as sensitive as microtiter plate IgM enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) (98–100). Other rapid assays include the latex agglutination assay (101) and lateral-flow assay (102). Positive rapid IgM results from patients in areas where leptospirosis is endemic should be interpreted with caution due to antibodies that circulate months to years following exposure or infection with leptospirosis (91). Ideally, rapid tests should be confirmed with MAT using paired serum samples to demonstrate a rise in titer to distinguish a new infection from a prior exposure in areas of endemicity.

sect2.title: ANTIBIOTIC SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Leptospires are susceptible to many antimicrobial agents, including β-lactams, macrolides, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and streptomycin. Problems in the determination of susceptibility include the long incubation time required (103), the use of media containing serum (104, 105), and the difficulty in quantifying growth accurately. These constraints have limited the development of rapid, standardized methods for susceptibility testing. However, broth microdilution methods have been described (106), and these have facilitated the testing of larger numbers of isolates against a wide range of antimicrobial agents (107). Such studies will lead to the identification of potential new agents for inclusion in clinical trials. More recently, gradient diffusion methods have been used to generate antimicrobial susceptibility data (108).

A metareview of clinical trials evaluating treatment for leptospirosis was unable to draw conclusions regarding benefits of antibiotic therapy, likely due primarily to the wide range of illness severity in patients. Regardless, intravenous penicillin, intravenous cephalosporins, doxycycline, and azithromycin were deemed appropriate for treatment (109–112). Likewise, it is widely believed that prophylaxis with once-weekly oral doxycycline can give short-term protection in high-risk environments and is effective at preventing disease (109); however, clinical trials have failed to demonstrate a clear benefit of prophylaxis (113).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: A diagnosis of leptospirosis can be made by isolation of the organism or by amplification of leptospiral DNA from blood, urine, or other specimens, by demonstration of leptospires in tissues by immunohistochemical staining, or by detection of a 4-fold or greater rise in titer between acute- and convalescent-phase serum samples tested by the same method at the same time. In populations and/or regions where leptospirosis is not endemic, MAT titers of ≥200 in a single specimen obtained after the onset of symptoms are suggestive but not diagnostic of acute or recent leptospirosis. A titer of ≥800 in the presence of compatible symptoms is strong evidence of recent or current leptospirosis. Delayed seroconversions are common. Assays that detect IgM antibodies give presumptive evidence of recent exposure to leptospirosis but require confirmation by another method, such as the MAT, since IgM titers are persistent (90). Negative test results in the presence of compatible symptoms do not rule out the diagnosis of leptospirosis, and further samples should be examined.

Despite recent advances in molecular detection and characterization of leptospires and in the development of rapid serologic tests, there are still relatively few laboratories throughout the world with the appropriate capacity to performLeptospira diagnostics. In the United States, leptospirosis was reinstated as a nationally notifiable disease in January 2013. Instructions for specimen submission and case reporting are available at the CDC website (https://www.cdc.gov/leptospirosis/). Additional information regarding leptospirosis is available at the Leptospira Library website (http://leptospira.amc.nl/leptospira-library/), and a current list of international diagnostic centers of expertise is available on the International Leptospirosis Society (ILS) website (http://www.leptosociety.org/).

The findings and conclusions in this report are those of the authors and do not necessarily represent the views of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention or the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry.
